[File: aptos-core/types/src/account_config/events/key_rotation.rs] [Struct: KeyRotation] [Weak key rotation] Can an attacker rotate to deliberately weak authentication keys (e.g., keys with known private keys) and emit valid KeyRotation events? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/account_config/events/key_rotation.rs] [Struct: KeyRotation] [Key reuse across accounts] Can the same authentication key be rotated to multiple different accounts, and do the KeyRotation events properly track this to prevent confusion in OriginatingAddress? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/account_config/events/key_rotation.rs] [Function: try_from_bytes()] [Error handling inconsistency] Does try_from_bytes() handle all BCS error cases consistently, or are there edge cases where it panics instead of returning Err? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/account_config/events/key_rotation.rs] [Struct: KeyRotation] [Unicode/encoding issues] Can non-UTF8 or malformed byte sequences in authentication keys cause issues when events are serialized to JSON for API responses? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/account_config/events/key_rotation.rs] [Struct: KeyRotation] [Null byte injection] Can authentication keys containing null bytes (\x00) bypass string-based validation in downstream systems? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/account_config/events/key_rotation.rs] [Struct: KeyRotation] [Boundary value testing] Have all boundary cases been tested: keys at exactly 32 bytes, keys just over/under size limits, maximum Vec capacity? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/account_config/events/key_rotation.rs] [Function: try_from_bytes()] [Partial deserialization] Can partially deserialized KeyRotation structs be created if deserialization fails midway, leading to undefined state? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/account_config/events/key_rotation.rs] [Struct: KeyRotation] [Concurrent rotation race] Can two transactions rotate the same account's key simultaneously in parallel execution, creating conflicting KeyRotation events? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/account_config/events/key_rotation.rs] [Struct: KeyRotation] [Event handle race] If KeyRotationEvent and KeyRotation events are both being emitted during migration, can race conditions cause events to be lost or duplicated? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/account_config/events/key_rotation.rs] [Static: KEY_ROTATION_TYPE] [Static initialization race] In a multi-threaded validator, can race conditions during Lazy initialization of KEY_ROTATION_TYPE cause non-deterministic behavior? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/account_config/events/key_rotation.rs] [Struct: KeyRotation] [Read-modify-write race] Can an attacker exploit time-of-check-time-of-use bugs where the old_authentication_key is read, validated, and then a rotation occurs before the event is emitted? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/account_config/events/key_rotation.rs] [Derive: Serialize, Deserialize] [Serde exploit] Can custom Deserialize implementations be injected to bypass validation when KeyRotation is deserialized from untrusted sources? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/account_config/events/key_rotation.rs] [Derive: Debug] [Information leakage] Does the Debug implementation expose sensitive authentication key material in logs or error messages that could be exploited? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/account_config/events/key_rotation.rs] [Struct: KeyRotation] [Clone absence] Since KeyRotation doesn't implement Clone, can this create issues in code that needs to duplicate events, potentially leading to use-after-move bugs? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/account_config/events/key_rotation.rs] [Struct: KeyRotation] [Send/Sync safety] Is KeyRotation properly Send + Sync for concurrent processing, or could it be transferred across thread boundaries unsafely? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/account_config/events/key_rotation.rs] [Struct: KeyRotation] [Drop implementation] Since drop is implemented, is there any cleanup logic that could fail or leave the system in an inconsistent state? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/account_config/events/key_rotation.rs] [Struct: KeyRotation] [Sequence number bypass] Can KeyRotation events be used to bypass sequence number validation by making it appear an account has been compromised and recovered? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/account_config/events/key_rotation.rs] [Struct: KeyRotation] [Gas manipulation] Can emitting many KeyRotation events with large authentication keys be used to manipulate gas pricing or exhaust gas limits? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/account_config/events/key_rotation.rs] [Struct: KeyRotation] [Validator slashing bypass] Can malicious validators manipulate KeyRotation events to avoid slashing by claiming their keys were compromised and rotated? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/account_config/events/key_rotation.rs] [Struct: KeyRotation] [Governance attack] Can KeyRotation events for governance-controlled accounts be manipulated to change voting power or proposal outcomes? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/account_config/events/key_rotation.rs] [Struct: KeyRotation] [Staking pool manipulation] Can KeyRotation events be exploited to manipulate staking pool ownership or delegation relationships? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/account_config/events/key_rotation.rs] [Struct: KeyRotation] [REST API injection] When KeyRotation events are serialized for REST API responses, can malicious key bytes cause JSON injection or parsing errors? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/account_config/events/key_rotation.rs] [Struct: KeyRotation] [GraphQL schema mismatch] Do event indexers properly handle all possible authentication key formats when indexing KeyRotation events, or can malformed keys break indexing? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/account_config/events/key_rotation.rs] [Struct: KeyRotation] [Websocket event flooding] Can an attacker emit excessive KeyRotation events to overwhelm websocket connections that subscribe to account events? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/account_config/events/key_rotation.rs] [Function: try_from_bytes()] [API deserialization] When events are fetched via API and deserialized client-side, can malicious bytes in the response exploit client-side BCS parsers? (Medium)
